page.syntax: Date_Time_Value as T = Time_Var(N year ,N month ,N day ,N hour ,N minutes ,N seconds [,C am_pm ])

argument.name: Date_Time_Value
argument.description: A Time variable with the specified date time value.

argument.name: month
argument.description: The number of the month (January = 1). One or two digits. Numeric

argument.name: day
argument.description: The day of the month. One or two digits. Numeric

argument.name: hour
argument.description: The hour of the day (noon = 12). One or two digits. If you use a 12 hour notation, use the AM_PM field to specify before or after mid-day. Numeric

argument.name: minutes
argument.description: The minute of the hour. One or two digits. Numeric

argument.name: seconds
argument.description: The seconds of the minute. Decimal values are allowed. Numeric

argument.name: am_pm
argument.description: Specifies before or after mid-day. Character. Optional. "a" = before mid-day, "p" = after mid-day

page.discussion: The TIME_VAR() function creates a date time variable (type T). This function is very useful when you want to compute the elapsed time between two date time values that cross date boundaries.
